items.title: Bringing static type syntax into JavaScript itself
items.content:
ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ #â€‹580 â€” March 11, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

ğŸ¤¦ Thanks to all readers who noticed we made a mistake with last week's subject line "TypeScript 2.6 released" â€“ rather than the intended 4.6.Â We were only 4 years late with that news ;-) Rest assured, more caffeine has been consumed today..

JavaScript Weekly

Credit: Daniel Rosenwasser

An ECMAScript Proposal for Type Annotations in JavaScript (That Are Ignored atÂ Runtime) â€” A huge amount of chatter this week over an interesting proposal to support type annotations directly in standard JavaScript code that are available for external type checkers to use but which are otherwise ignored at runtime. TypeScriptâ€™s Daniel Rosenwasser has written a lot more about the approach here. Dr. Axel has also written up his thoughts. Whatever the case, people seem pretty excited for the potential and Allen Wirfs-Brock has said "if I was still active on TC39 Iâ€™d be advocating for this proposal."

Tayar, Rosenwasser, Cintra, Palmer, et al.

Wallaby.js: 15x Faster JavaScript/Jest Testing and Debugging â€” Wallaby runs your tests immediately as you type, with runtime values, errors and code coverage displayed in real-time right next to your code. Features have been designed specifically for testing, including: time-travel debugging, edit-and-continue support, and muchÂ more.

Wallaby.js sponsor

React 18 Release Candidate Released â€” The full production release of React 18 is seemingly imminent: just out, the detailed documentation covering the upgrade to this weekâ€™s release candidate. The post also includes useful information about some of the major newÂ features.

Rick Hanlon and React Core Team

ğŸ¦ Â Twitter Thread on Stripe Converting from Flow to TypeScript â€” And it took just one weekend: â€œWe modified about 3.5 million lines of code, and then hundreds of developers came in Monday morning ready to writeÂ TS.â€

Andrew Lunny on Twitter

WebGPU â€” All of the Cores, None of the Canvas â€” Itâ€™s always a pleasure to see Surma dig into something (especially Web Workers) and this time he turns to making the potential of WebGPU (an API that exposes the capabilities of GPU hardware that, admittedly, isn't available by default in any standard browser yet) more accessible to usÂ all.

Surma

IN BRIEF:

  • Did you know that for legacy reasons HTML-style comments work in JavaScript? (A quirk that adds some additional complexity to V8's parser..)

  • A fascinating Twitter thread diving straight down the rabbit hole of historic calendars and why JS and Swift disagree on when January 1, 1 AD actuallyÂ was.

  • Chrome has made some big leaps forward in browser performance in the past year and now claims to be faster than Safari.

  • The Views on Vue podcast has an episode covering â–¶ï¸ the growth of the ViteÂ ecosystem.

RELEASES:

Partytown 0.5.0 â€“ Moves scripts into Web Workers for perf.
AVA 4.1.0 â€“ Node.js test runner.
Rollup.js 2.70.0 â€“ ES module bundler.
Node 17.7.0 and 17.7.1
React Native DateTimePicker 6.0

ğŸ’» Jobs

JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Senior React Engineer @ Nebulab (Remote) â€” Join our distributed team and build high-volume eCommerce applications in a workplace made by developers forÂ developers.
Nebulab

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Naming Conflicts â€“ or How Existing Code Can Force Proposed Features to Be Renamed â€” Phil Karlton once said â€œcache invalidation and naming thingsâ€ were the two hardest things in computer science, and JavaScript has had its fair share of trouble around theÂ latter.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

A Lightweight GitHub REST API in 34 Lines of Code â€” The power of ES proxies strikes again. Not a tutorial, but you might learn something from theÂ code.

David Wells

Project Management for Today's (And Tomorrow's) Software Team â€” We bring the flow to your software team's workflow. Plan, collaborate, build, and measure success withÂ Shortcut.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Building Serverless Multi-Region WebSocket APIs on AWS â€” A look at an interesting (and very AWS-y!) architecture for a global real-time chat app by using WebSockets and cross-region communications behind theÂ scenes.

Freiberg and Ziller (AWS)

My Experience Building a Chess App in React â€” The author describes himself as a self-taught, relative newcomer to React development. As a result, he describes his approach to this well-defined problem in terms that those at a similar point in the learning curve will find easy toÂ understand.

Fred Litt

Creating Native Web Components â€” Looks at how to create native web components using the Minze JavaScriptÂ framework.

Sergej Samsonenko

The Tools that Developers Needâ€“and Don't Needâ€“to Build GreatÂ Chatbots

Botpress Technologies, Inc. sponsor

How to Build a File Upload Service with Vanilla JavaScript
Pankaj Tanwar

A Complete Guide to TypeScriptâ€™s never Type
Zhenghao He

Making a Discord Playlist Bot with Serverless Cloud
Ben Miner

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

LemonadeJS V2: A Reactive JavaScript Library with Zero TranspilingÂ Needed â€” Simple, straightforward reactivity anywhere with as little tooling surrounding it asÂ possible.

LemonadeJS Team

striff: Real Simple String Diffing â€” Given two strings, you can find out which characters were added or removed, andÂ where.

Alex MacArthur

PSD: A Zero-Dependency PSD (Photoshop) Parser â€” Will parse info for each layer including text and also supports Photoshopâ€™s .PSB (big image) format. GitHubÂ repo.

webtoon

Studio 3T Manages Your Data, While You Wrestle Your App into Shape â€” Studio 3T's full suite of MongoDB tools lets you develop with data even faster and turn queries intoÂ code.

Studio 3T sponsor

Tygo: Generate TypeScript Types from Go(lang) Source Code â€” Letâ€™s say youâ€™re building an app with Go on the backend and TypeScript on the frontend. This tool scans your Go-based API and creates the relevant TypeScript types forÂ you.

Guido Zuidhof

Reason: Write Fast, Type Safe Code in OCaml, But for the JS Ecosystem â€” You essentially get to write OCaml but compile toÂ JavaScript.

Facebook

Ultra: A Modern Streaming React Framework for Deno â€” Built around native browser features like ES modules, import maps, and web streams. The source of the projectâ€™s own Ultra-powered homepage may help you weigh up if you like its cutting edge approach orÂ not.

Omar Mashaal et al.

ğŸ®Â And for some fun..

micropolisJS: A JavaScript Clone of a SimCity-Like Game â€” I didnâ€™t get on to the SimCity train until SimCity 2000, but if you liked the vibe of the earlier 1989 version of SimCity, this might be a reasonable way to fritter away someÂ time.

Graeme McCutcheon

items.title: TypeScript 2.6 released
items.content:
#â€‹579 â€” March 4, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

TypeScript 4.6 Released (And It Even Benefits Non-TS Users!) â€” The typed superset of JavaScript takes another step forward with the addition of the es2022 target, allowing code in constructors before super(), improved recursion depth checks, more syntax errors that can be detected in JavaScript files if using VS Code (even if you're not developing in TypeScript yourself!), andÂ more.

Daniel Rosenwasser

Five Things You Don't Need JavaScript for â€” We love JS, but CSS and SVG have progressed enough to replace some traditional JS useÂ cases.

Steven Waterman

The Easiest Way to Monitor Node: Automatic Instrumentation â€” Monitoring your Node.js apps can be hard. You need to understand what you need to monitor, instrument code, and then make sense of all the data. Automatic instrumentation makes that whole process easier and streamlined. Find out how you can doÂ it.

AppSignal sponsor

Socket: See Potential Security Issues for npm Packages â€” An interesting new project that scans the code of each npm package in an attempt to characterize their behavior, which is then reported on project specific pages, such as this one for lodash or this one for zx. Early days but some potentially useful infoÂ here.

Socket

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ Leaflet Project Appeals to JS Developers for Ukraine â€” Did you know the popular Leaflet mapping library was created by a Ukrainian developer? The Leaflet team has a message to share about the current invasion and how you can help. We, too, have donated and will continue to do so. In related news, GitHub has also shared their response to theÂ war.

Leaflet.js

IN BRIEF:

  • Another month, another VS Code release. This time we get improved automatic language detection, lazy variable evaluation when debugging JS (and JS only, for now), and improved syntax error reporting in JS files.

  • ğŸ“† DevOps.js is a virtual conference on building, deploying, and monitoring JS apps taking place in just three weeks (March 24-25). You can register here.

  • Apple, Bocoup, Google, Mozilla and others have announced Interop 2022, a collaboration to improve interoperability of (mostly visual, for now) Web technologies.

  • The much loved and heavily used MDN Web Docs site now has a new homepage, design, and logo.

RELEASES:

Ember 4.2 â€“ The opinionated framework.
zx 5.2 â€“ Replace bash scripts with JavaScript.
React-Bootstrap 2.2 â€“ Bootstrap components built with React.
Nest.js 8.4 â€“ Node.js server-side framework.
deck.gl 8.7 â€“ WebGL2 powered visualization framework.
OpenPGP.js 5.2 â€“ JS OpenPGP implementation.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Senior Frontend Engineer (React) â€” Remote / NYC â€” We're the leading spend management platform for businesses. Small cross-functional front-end operations using React andÂ TypeScript.
Ramp

Ashby (YCW19) Is Hiring Engineers Who Want Ownership â€” Join a remote-first team improving productivity with powerful software. <2h meetings/wk. Ship >8x per day. CI/CD takes <10minÂ ğŸš€
Ashby

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Enhancements to the Ubiquitous 2D HTML Canvas â€” Canvas is heavily used around the Web in its Canvas2D guise (up to 40% of pages, apparently?) and this post looks at some of the newer features and enhancements being made toÂ it.

Aaron Krajeski (Google)

The Most Modern JavaScript I Know (in One Script) â€” This is a cute idea that maybe we could all try when learning things. Bram has produced a single piece of code, jamming in every new JS concept they justÂ learned.

Bram Wasti

Cheat Sheet: OWASP Top 10 Vulnerabilities (And How to Fix Them) â€” Spoiler alert - Broken Access Control is the #1 risk. Learn actionable tips to prevent each top 10Â vulnerability.

Snyk sponsor

How Do Primitive Values Get Their Properties? â€” Dr. Axel is back with the second part of a series on primitive values. This time he looks at how primitive values can be used as if objects and where their properties are actually coming from. For example: 'xy'.length.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

â–¶Â Â Kent C. Dodds's (Classic) Beginner's Guide to React Course â€” The folks at Egghead, a place that offers various online courses, is releasing some of their â€˜classicâ€™ courses on YouTube, and the first one is a React course from Kent C. Dodds. Itâ€™s 2.5 hours long, uses React 16, and dates from early 2020, so itâ€™s not out of date :-)

Kent C Dodds (Egghead)

'SolidJS Feels Like What I Always Wanted React to Be' â€” An opinionated piece. SolidJS is an efficient reactive UI library and weâ€™ve seen direct comparisons before â€“ this piece goes intoÂ specifics.

Nick Scialli

Use Group Step Type to Better Organize Complex Pipelines âœ¨

Buildkite sponsor

A Guide to Audio Visualization with JavaScript and GSAP â€” The author built an audio visualization feature for Kent C Doddâ€™s newÂ site.

Jhey Tompkins

â–¶Â Â Ten React Anti-Patterns to Avoid
Fireship

Implementing Tetris Using React in 200 Lines of Code
Niall Crosby

How OkCupid Open Sourced an ESLint Plugin for Internationalization
Xiaoyun Yang

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Reveal.js 4.3: An HTML Presentation Framework â€” Brings elegant presentations to anyone with a Web browser. v4.3 just came out with a fewÂ tweaks.

Hakim El Hattab

Redux Toolkit 1.8.0 Released â€” If youâ€™re down with Redux for managing state, the â€œofficial, opinionated, batteries-included toolset for efficient Redux developmentâ€ is what you need :-) Among other things, this release adds new â€˜listenerâ€™ middleware (think useEffect but for Redux storeÂ updates).

Mark Erikson and the Redux Team

Million 1.5: A Fast Virtual DOM Implementation â€” Focused on performance and shipping at under 1KB compressed, Million is ideal if you want an agnostic VDOM implementation to use when building your own framework orÂ libraries.

Million

Shortcut Puts the Agile in Agile and the â€œCanâ€ in Kanban

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦ Â Made in Ukraine: A List of (Mostly JS) Projects Built by UkrainianÂ Developers â€” More projects than you may have realized.

ChernivtsiJS

dnt: Deno-to-Node Package Transformation Tool â€” Takes a Deno module and creates an npm package for use in Node. Goes further than mere packaging though and actually injects shims, transforms commonly Deno code forms to Node approaches, andÂ more.

Deno Team

ml-matrix 6.9: Matrix Manipulation and Computation Library
ml.js

Dynamodump 2.0: A CLI Tool for Backing Up and Restoring Schema and Data to/fromÂ DynamoDB
Mikael Finstad

items.title: How to read the spec behind JavaScript
items.content:
#â€‹578 â€” February 25, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

What Are Wrapper Objects for JavaScript's PrimitiveÂ Values? â€” Dr. Axel talks about how primitive types like boolean and string have associated wrapper classes (e.g. Boolean and String) and demonstrates the value theyÂ provide.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

How to Read the ECMAScript Specification â€” Each time thereâ€™s a new ECMAScript spec we link to it - such as this draft ES2022 spec.. but who reads such a complex and intimidating document? This is a neat dig into how the spec ticks formatting wise and why the spec is worth a skim at theÂ least.

Timothy Gu

Learn the Fundamentals of Rx.js â€” This useful JavaScript library is great for managing events that happen over time, and in this detailed video course Steve Kinney covers what you need to know to make use of it â€” including observables, events, intervals, timers, operators, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

ğŸ“„ PDF:Â From JavaScript to Rust: A Book â€” A book that attempts to map common JavaScript workflows to the Rust ecosystem, if youâ€™ve been keen to pick up the increasingly popular systems language. Thereâ€™s also a GitHub repo with the source for theÂ book.

Jarrod Overson

Cheerp 2.7: Compile C++ to WebAssembly and JavaScript â€” The latest version of a unique tool (built upon the clang compiler) that provides JavaScript-C++ interoperability gains ES modules support and produces faster and smaller output thanÂ before.

Carlo Piovesan

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸŸ© Node 17.6.0 has been released with initial (and experimental) support for loading ES modules over HTTPS.

  • Glitch is a neat online app building environment well suited to JavaScript apps, and you can now deploy Glitch apps to DigitalOcean. They're also collaborating with Fastly.

  • The â–¶ï¸ story of TypeScript told in 6 minutes. And if you like this format, there's the â–¶ï¸ story of asynchronous JavaScript too!

RELEASES:

Playwright 1.19 â€“ Browser automation library.
neo.mjs 3.2.5 â€“ Web Worker enhanced frontend framework.
Jasmine 4.0.1 â€“ JS testing framework.
Resemble.js 4.1 â€“ Image analysis and comparison library.
eva.js 1.2.7 â€“ Front-end game engine.
History 5.3 â€“ Manage session history with JS.
qooxdoo 7.0 â€“ SPA framework we last mentioned 7 yrs ago(!)

ğŸ’» Jobs

Work Remotely Forever â€” When you join Toptal, you get the freedom of freelance with the security of full-time. Take control of your careerÂ today.
Toptal

JavaScript Developer at X-Team (Remote) â€” Join the most energizing community for developers and work on long-term projects for Riot Games, FOX, Sony, Coinbase, andÂ more.
X-Team

Fullstack Engineer (Remote, EU Timezones) â€” Weâ€™ve built a product thousands of people love (See Trustpilot if you donâ€™t believe us). We need your help with Node &Â TypeScript.
Feather

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How to Reliably Send an HTTP Request on Leaving a Page â€” Browsers donâ€™t guarantee to preserve open HTTP requests when changing pages but there are some mitigations or alternative approaches (e.g. beacons).

Alex MacArthur

How To Develop a Text Editor for the Web â€” The engineer at a company building a browser-based design tool reflects on some of the technical issues of producing a reliable text entryÂ widget.

Ilya Medvedev

3k+ Devs Completed the State of Frontend 2022 - It's Your Turn â€” 3k devs and counting - we need you too! Take 8 minutes click through the survey, and catch the outcomeÂ soon.

The Software House sponsor

Future JavaScript: A Look at Records and Tuples â€” Two years ago we mentioned the record and tuples proposal (two new deeply immutable primitive types for JS) had reached stage 2 at TC39. Itâ€™s still there.. but a polyfill brings them to BabelÂ users.

Johnny Simpson

You Can throw() Anything In JavaScript (And Other async/await Considerations) â€” The author experiments with throw and ends up questioning his mental model of errorÂ handling.

Ben Nadel

â–¶Â Â What is Responsible JavaScript? â€” The author of Responsible JavaScript talks about topics like responsible data usage, user experience, backwards compatibility, etc. (55Â minutes.)

Smashing Magazine Podcast podcast

How to Make a Data Dashboard with React Native

InfluxData sponsor

How to Use nextTick() in Vue â€” nextTick(callback) executes the callback when the DOM has beenÂ updated.

Dmitri Pavlutin

Optimizing Third-Party Script Loading in Next.js
Leena Sohoni and Houssein Djirdeh (Google)

â–¶Â Â 10 Things You Should Know About Lodash in 3 Minutes
EzBackend

Comparing Gatsby and Next.js
Alex Barashkov

Implementing the Game of Life with React, Hooks and Chakra-UI
Ruslan Elishaev

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Screenshot: No-Dependency Browser-Native Screenshot Library â€” Uses the MediaDevices API but provides an easier to use abstract for letting users take screenshots. GitHubÂ repo.

Tejas Kumar

Introducing FormKit: A Vue 3 Form Building Framework â€” A complete form building framework inspired by earlier work on Vue Formulate. GitHubÂ repo.

Justin Schroeder

Stylo: An Open Source WYSIWYG Rich Text Editor for JavaScript â€” Lightweight, no dependencies, and you can configure the default toolbar to suit your app's specificÂ needs.

David Dal Busco

More Cloud for Less Money â€” Vultr offers developers Cloud Compute instances as low as $2.50 per month. Try Vultr for 14 days with this freeÂ credit.

Vultr sponsor

Beam: Node.js-Powered and GitHub-Inspired Message Board forÂ Teams â€” Beam is a message board inspired by a similar proprietary system used for team communication at GitHub. GitHubÂ repo.

PlanetScale

Stockfish.js: A Chess Engine â€” Stockfish is a popular chess engine usually written in C++ but this project brings it into JS contexts by way ofÂ WebAssembly.

Nathan Rugg

ğŸ˜† Â Elevator.js: An Old Fashioned 'Scroll to Top'Â Button â€” Just a bitÂ ofÂ fun.
Tim Holman

enum-xyz: JavaScript Enums using Proxies â€” Fun little reader-submittedÂ idea.
Chase Fleming

JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
What Are Wrapper Objects for JavaScript's PrimitiveÂ Values? â€” Dr. Axel talks about how primitive types like boolean and string have associated wrapper classes (e.g. Boolean and String) and demonstrates the value theyÂ provide.
Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

items.title: The State of JS results are in
items.content:
#â€‹577 â€” February 18, 2022

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The State of JS 2021 Results â€” Despite saying 2021, the survey took place this January, so the results are up to date and represent the answers given by the 16,085 respondents. As with any survey or poll, be careful in how you interpret the results (many folks have noted problems around diversity or methodology) but nonetheless we always enjoy seeing the results from year to year and seeing what people have mentioned. Highlights:

  • esbuild was the tool with the largest year on year satisfaction growth.
  • 5.6% of respondents are using Deno.
  • Long standing libraries Axios, Lodash and Moment remain the most popular.
  • Syntax is by far the most popular podcast but there are 24 others in the list to check out.
  • TypeScript is by far the most common alternative 'flavor' of JavaScript, with Elm a distant second place.
  • Shawn 'swyx' Wang has a neat round up / conclusion post.

Sacha Greif

JavaScript Scratchpad for VS Code, Now with CodeÂ Stories â€” Quokka.js is the #1 tool for exploring and testing JavaScript. Code runs immediately as you type. The new Code Story Viewer provides a unique and highly efficient way of inspecting runtime values to see what your code is doing in a single continuousÂ view.

Wallaby.js sponsor

Express.js 5.0 Now in Beta â€” Considering that the first alpha of 5.0 was over seven years ago, this is a big step for the still wildly popular and influential Node.js Web app library. Thereâ€™s also thorough docs of the 5.x APIÂ here.

Express.js Team

IN BRIEF:

  • Microsoft's Angela Zhang writes about how Microsoft has been improving React Native's ability to call Windows APIs and how it's already being used in part of Windows 11.

  • Version 100 of both Chrome and Firefox will soon be with us, so it's time to think about if your code can cope and to test things out.

  • ğŸ‘¾ Enjoyed the Wordle word game? Jazle is Wordle but for JavaScript package/project names.

  • Joyent has transferred the Node.js trademarks to the OpenJS Foundation.

  • Google has unveiled the next version of its Cloud Functions serverless platform with longer function running times, bigger instances, and more.

  • ESLint 8.9.0 has landed with a new es2022 environment added.

RELEASES:

Next.js 12.1
TypeScript 4.6 Release Candidate 1
Remix 1.2 â€“ The freshest full-stack JS framework in town.
zx 5.1 â€“ Better shell scripting with JS.
Strapi 4.1.0 â€“ Headless Node.js CMS system.
Cypress 9.5.0 â€“ Popular testing system.

ğŸ’» Jobs

Director of Engineering @ ButterCMS (Remote) â€” Working closely with our founder and CEO, youâ€™ll own all technology, deliver on our roadmap, and most importantly, ensure that our customers areÂ successful.
ButterCMS

Senior JavaScript Developer (Remote) â€” Get featured directly to tech companies hiring JavaScript developers right now. Land an interview in as little as 24Â hrs.
Arc

Join the Worldâ€™s Largest Remote Workforce â€” We offer the freedom of freelance with the security of full-time. Start working remotely with the worldâ€™s top clientsÂ today.
Toptal

Stream is Hiring in Boulder, Amsterdam and Remote.
Stream

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How to Track Down Code Responsible for Polluting the Global Scope â€” You might not want code adding global variables to the window object, and itâ€™s possible to work out where things are goingÂ wrong when itÂ does.

Matteo Mazzarolo

The Basics of package.json â€” Most likely youâ€™ve been working with package.json files for years, but it can pay to refamiliarize yourself with their manyÂ properties.

Gabby T and Marian Villa (NodeScource)

A Deep Dive into React Nativeâ€™s New Architecture â€” A new architecture for React Native is being rolled out in 2022, as described in this post from the React Native team. Here are some independentÂ observations.

Atharva Patil

100+ Fully Native Components for High-Quality Modern Angular UI â€” Get every component you need to build an enterprise-ready app. Kendo UI for Angular can cover any UI requirements your team may have â€” with themes, documentation andÂ more.

Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

ğŸ† Â JavaScript to Know for React â€” A golden oldie weâ€™ve seen doing the rounds again this week. It remains a perfect primer of several key JS features though with examples of features that will help you with React development inÂ particular.

Kent C Dodds

Monorepos Explained â€” A new site that rounds up pretty much anything you need to know about monorepos, and the tools to buildÂ them.

Nrwl

Mimicking Rust's Result Type in 7 Lines of TypeScript
Huy Tran

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

v8n 1.4: A 'Fluent Validation' Library â€” Chain together rules to make validations, e.g. v8n().some.not.uppercase().test("Hello");

Bruno C. Couto

Neat Example of Using a JS Proxy as a Low Code REST Client â€” If youâ€™ve never fiddled with Proxy before, this might sell you on a useÂ case.

David Wells

Project Management for Software Teams Has Never Been Easier â€” Shortcut is fast and intuitive project management built for developers. Delight the scrum gods and try itÂ now.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

TypeIt: A Versatile 'Typewriter Effect' â€” If you need an effect to look like someone is â€˜typingâ€™ on a Web page, this is for you. Alternatively you could create your own from scratch or, if youâ€™re using React, consider Windups.

Alex MacArthur

Marked 4: A Fast Markdown Parser and Compiler â€” Works in the browser or server-side. Demo here to see it inÂ action.

Christopher Jeffrey

Minze: A JavaScript Framework for Native Web Components â€” Based on the latest web component standards and it allows you to build portable component libraries that you can use on anyÂ project.

Sergej Samsonenko

Heart Switch: A Heart-Shaped Toggle Switch Component for React â€” Built with accessibility in mind and a late Valentineâ€™s Day gift for you all, perhaps. You can test it outÂ here.

Anatoliy Gatt

Stream Is Hiring in Boulder, Amsterdam and Remote. Join the Team,Â Today

Stream sponsor

discord-styled-releases: A GitHub Action That Sends Release Messages to Your DiscordÂ Server
Nico Hevia

ğŸ˜Â Well, that's useful!

GitHub has added a handy feature to its custom variant of Markdown so that you can write diagrams directly in Markdown using the same format as Mermaid.js. This is a fantastic way to make your README files more interesting if you have processes that can be outlined by way of a diagram â€“ so check it out.

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
